Award.AwardTitle: Development and Synthetic Applications of [1,3] and [3,3] Rearrangements of O-Vinyl Oximes
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Laura L. Anderson of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Illinois at Chicago will explore the synthetic applications of the [1,3] and [3,3] rearrangements of O-vinyl oximes for more efficient access to important stereodefined organic fragments such as alpha-amino ketones, 1,4-imino ketones, beta-amino alcohols, gamma-amino alcohols, and heterocycles. Prior use of O-vinyl oximes in organic synthesis has been hampered by a lack of general methods for their preparation. This program builds on recent discoveries of simple methods for the preparation of O-vinyl oximes and initial observations of the tunability of their rearrangement reactions. Collection of fundamental reactivity and mechanistic data will be used to guide the development of stereoselective and catalytic processes and to harness the potential of these underutilized important synthons. Rearrangement products of O-vinyl oximes will be further derivitized using the stereochemical information set during the sigmatropic rearrangements to provide rapid access to complicated, stereodefined, organic fragments.

This project could transform an unused organic compound into a valuable and versatile organic synthon, providing new tools for the retrosynthetic analysis of synthetic targets and the elucidation of new efficient pathways to important pharmaceuticals and materials. The fundamental studies outlined in the proposal could rapidly elucidate the most potent applications of these underutilized intermediates and this approach to synthetic method development will also function as a means to train an ethnic and gender diverse group of graduate and undergraduate students to find creative solutions to synthetic challenges and prepare them to positively impact the chemical community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the three year funding period, we designed new copper-mediated methods for the synthesis of reactive intermediates containing weak N–O bonds, which are poised to undergo a variety of rearrangement and cascade reactions to form challenging C–C, C–N, and C–O bonds in desirable organic structural motifs.  While we had originally only targeted O-vinyloximes and divinylhydroxylamines as our key reactive intermediates, our exploration of the Chan-Lam reaction for the functionalization of oximes also provided us with a convenient route to N-alkenyl- and N-arylketonitrones.  We discovered that these intermediates also provide mechanistically-related convenient routes and orthogonal approaches to challenging synthetic fragments such as alpha-oxygenated ketones, alpha-iminoketones, 1,4-enaminoketones, alpha-(ortho-anilido)ketones, highly substituted pyrroles and pyridines, as well as novel indole-based heterocycles such as dihydropyridoindoles and dihydrocarbazoles.  In addition to discovering the reactions themselves, we also achieved our goals of rendering these transformations diastereoselective and enantioselective.  The advances that we have achieved will benefit both the development of new pharmaceutically active reagents, as well as the design of new organic materials, by providing new, highly efficient routes to commonly challenging synthons.  In addition, this work will impact fundamental new method development by inspiring new applications of these previously underutilized intermediates.

Beyond the scientific impact of the work done during the funding period on the synthetic community, this project has had a broader impact through the education of graduate students, undergraduate students, and high school students involved in the project.  Specifically, this project has provided a framework for the graduate studies of nine graduate students, the research experiences of six undergraduates, and the research experience of a high school student.  In particular, six out of the nine graduate students were women.  In addition, one facet of the project was developed into a teaching lab where 18 students prepared new dihydropyridoindole heterocycles using our methods.

In summary, our exploration of the preparation and reactivity of intermediates containing N-O bonds has led to the discovery of new efficient methods for the preparation of challenging motifs in biologically active compounds and structural components of organic materials.  The broader impact of this work has been in the education of graduate and undergraduate students as well as through the encouragement and success of women in chemistry. 

 


Last Modified: 07/24/2015
Modified by: Laura L Anderson

While we had originally only targeted O-vinyloximes and divinylhydroxylamines as our key reactive intermediates, our exploration of the Chan-Lam reaction for the functionalization of oximes also provided us with a convenient route to N-alkenyl- and N-arylketonitrones. Specifically, this project has provided a framework for the graduate studies of nine graduate students, the research experiences of six undergraduates, and the research experience of a high school student. In particular, six out of the nine graduate students were women. In summary, our exploration of the preparation and reactivity of intermediates containing N-O bonds has led to the discovery of new efficient methods for the preparation of challenging motifs in biologically active compounds and structural components of organic materials. The broader impact of this work has been in the education of graduate and undergraduate students as well as through the encouragement and success of women in chemistry.
